_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
Frontier Refining Inc.
Risk Management Program

Frontier?s Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
It is Frontier?s policy to design, construct, operate, and maintain the equipment at the Cheyenne Refinery so that no accidental releases of any chemical occur that would negatively impact people or the environment.  To this end, Frontier?s staff strives to conduct all activities in accordance with industry standards.  Frontier considers safety as a condition of employment and emphasizes safety in the workplace.  Personnel are required to demonstrate their commitment to safety by regularly attending safety meetings, being involved in one of two behavior-based safety programs, and undergoing regular refresher training on safety and environmental topics.

Source Description and Part 68 Regulated Substances Handled 
Frontier Refining Incorporated?s (Frontier?s) Cheyenne Refinery processes approximately 52,000 barrels per day of crude oil supplied from Canada, Wyoming, and adjacent states.  The refinery consists of approximately fifteen process units that separate, chemically react, and finally blend the crude oil components into gasoline, diesel, asphalt, petroleum coke, and other products.  In addition, the refinery has over one hundred storage tanks for storing the raw materials, intermediates, and products prior to shipment by pipeline or truck.

Three 40 CFR Part 68 regulated substances are present in the processes at the Frontier facility in amounts above the specified threshold quantities.  These substances are common to most petroleum refineries and are:

?    Chlorine, used to control algae growth in the refinery?s cooling towers.  Chlorine is a gas at normal conditions and is toxic above a certain concentration in the air.
?    NFPA 4 flammable mixtures that contain the regulated substances hydrogen, methane, ethane, propane, propene, butane, isobutane, butene, and/or pentane.  These substances are chemically reacted and/or blend

ed into gasoline and are flammable or explosive under certain conditions.
?    Anhydrous hydrogen fluoride (HF), used as a catalyst in Frontier?s Alkylation Unit.  HF is a gas at normal conditions and is toxic above a certain concentration in the air.

Frontier?s Accidental Release Program & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
Frontier implements and administers the RMP accidental release program through OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) program, which requires the same program elements.  Frontier has an individual designated as the PSM Manager who is responsible for the implementation and administration of the program.  There are eleven processes at the refinery which contain RMP-regulated substances above threshold quantities:

?    Cooling Water Treatment (chlorine)
?    LPG Storage (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    HF Alkylation Unit (NFPA 4 flammables and hydrofluoric acid)
?    Butamer Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Crude Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Naphtha Hydrotreating (Hydrobon) Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Catalytic Reforming (Platformer) Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Gasoline Hydrotreating (Scanfiner) Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit (FCCU) (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Gas Concentration Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)
?    Delayed Coking Unit (NFPA 4 flammables)

Chlorine is stored at the facility in 2,000 lb cylinders only.  This limits the amount that could be released by a cylinder failure.  

NFPA 4 flammable mixtures are used in several areas throughout the plant.  Frontier?s personnel are trained to be very aware of hydrocarbon leaks.  Through the Hot Work Permit program and the Leak Detection and Repair (LDAR) program, regular monitoring is conducted with calibrated instruments to check for and direct the repair of leaks.  Operators in all units have hand-held monitors for the detection of hydrocarbons, and several units have fixed hydrocarbon detectors.  Frontier also maintains firewater monitors, deluge systems, and water curtains near the areas.  

HF acid is present

only in the Alkylation Unit.  All personnel entering the unit receive special HF acid training prior to being allowed to enter.  Frontier?s personnel are trained to be very aware of HF leaks.  In addition, equipment connections are painted with a reactive paint that changes color in the presence of HF.  This provides indication of any leak at a connection.  In addition to the HF-specific measures, the measures outlined previously for NFPA 4 flammable substances also apply at the Alkylation Unit.  These measures are effective at detecting and mitigating HF leaks, since in most places in the unit, hydrocarbons are present with the HF acid, and HF acid is very soluble in water.  Open-path hydrocarbon monitors are installed in the unit.  Finally, closed-circuit video cameras are placed throughout the unit to aid the operators? monitoring of the unit and direct the deluge water cannons in the event of a release.

Frontier?s Five Year Accident History
In the past five years, Frontier has had two accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in injuries to company personnel as well as significant property damage on site.  Neither resulted in any deaths or known offsite impacts / environmental damage.  

On Monday, January 19, 2004, at approximately 2:00 pm, explosions occurred in both A and B heaters at the Coker Unit.  A fire erupted as fuel gas continued to flow from the heaters, and fractionator bottoms flowed from a failed A-heater feed line.  The incident was caused by an interruption in the instrument air pressure to the Coker Unit.  As a result, the A and B heater fuel and pilot gas control and chop (shutdown) valves closed, extinguishing the burner and pilot fires.  When the air pressure was restored, the heater fuel and pilot gas control and chop valves actuated to the open positions, filling the fireboxes with fuel and pilot gas. The internal firebox refractory temperature ignited the fuel-air mixture, resulting in an explosion in both A and B heaters.

There were no immediate personnel injuries due to the explosion; however, one operator was treated for smoke inhalation following the incident and a supervisor suffered a muscle strain during emergency response activities.

On Friday, January 5, 2007, at approximately 1:00 pm, an explosion and fire occurred at the Coker API Separator.  The resulting fire was contained and extinguished by Frontier Fire Rescue personnel by approximately 1:30 pm.  The separator was blanketed with firefighting foam as a precautionary measure, and the all-clear was sounded at approximately 2:00 pm.  There was one recordable injury associated with the incident.  The injured employee was transported by ambulance to the hospital for evaluation and treatment of a scalp wound and abrasions on the right hand.  The injured employee was released from the hospital on the same day.

Frontier?s Emergency Response Program
General
All refinery personnel, contract workers, and unescorted visitors are required to complete an annual basic facility hazards awareness program prior to proceeding onto the operational areas of the refinery.  This program includes how to recognize emergency alarms and what to do in the event an alarm is sounded.   

Frontier Employees
A majority of the refinery?s non-managerial and non-administrative employees, as well as some contractors undergo annual first responder training (approximately three hours).  This covers usage of a self-contained breathing apparatus, basic awareness of Frontier?s firefighting and spill response equipment, fire extinguisher training on a live fire, and usage of a fire hose.

Fire Brigade
Frontier?s Fire Brigade is comprised of forty facility personnel that respond to refinery emergency situations involving fires and/or hazardous materials, including those subject to RMP.  Fire Brigade personnel receive an initial 32-hour training in industrial firefighting at either Texas A&M University Fire School or University of Nevada-Elko Fire Science Aca

demy and an initial 24-hour OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) training held locally.  The Fire Brigade personnel also drill once a month for approximately four hours, attend an eight-hour HAZWOPER refresher course annually, and attend another 32-hour industrial firefighting course every three years.

Frontier maintains an on-site firehouse with several firefighting vehicles: a fast-attack truck, a 1250-gallon foam pumper, a 1250-gpm pumper engine, a 2000-gpm ?Hired Gun? self-educting foam nozzle trailer, and a 1200-gallon foam nurse trailer.  A 1250-gpm ?Telesquirt? pumper/ladder engine and a hazardous materials (HAZMAT) response trailer are stored offsite.  The HAZMAT trailer contains equipment primarily for spill containment, decontamination and cleanup.  Frontier also maintains a live fire fighting facility onsite.

Medical Personnel
Twenty-nine of Frontier?s employees are trained to respond to medical injuries to the Basic Emergency Care level.  This training consists of an initial 40-hour training as well as ongoing continuing education requirements and biannual certification.  Frontier also has one nurse on duty at the facility and six employees who are certified Emergency Medical Technicians.  Frontier retains a company doctor who has an office off site.

Incident Command 
Frontier has three employees trained as Incident Commanders using the National Interagency Incident Management System (NIIMS) Incident Command System (ICS).  These employees have received an initial eight-hour training in ICS.  Frontier conducts tabletop ICS drills approximately once a month.  Each incident commander, as well as other employees serving in the ICS, attend approximately three such drills per year.

In addition to the control rooms in the individual process units, Frontier?s facility is equipped with an underground central control room that can be used to control the facility remotely during an emergency.  An emergency operations center is locat

ed in close proximity to the central control room.

Offsite Responders Coordination
Frontier?s Fire Brigade participates in drills with the City of Cheyenne Fire Rescue once or twice a year and Frontier is a member of, and the Fire Chief participates in, the Laramie County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Emergency releases and significant fires are reported to the local 911, the Laramie County Emergency Management Agency, the Wyoming Office of Homeland Security, the Wyoming Department of Environmental Quality, and/or the National Response Center, as regulations require.  

Frontier is a founding member of the Laramie County Industrial Mutual Aid Organization, which includes the City and County fire departments as well as several industrial and military fire departments in the area.  The mutual aid organization can provide additional response equipment, materials, and personnel in the event of a large emergency.  The organization maintains and updates a directory of mutual aid resources.
  
Community Notification
In the event of an emergency event or a non-emergency event that may be mistaken for an emergency (e.g. fire training exercise), Frontier contacts the city 911 operator.  In the case of a large or highly visible event, the Laramie County Emergency Management Agency (LCEMA) may be notified as well.  Any community notifications, whether for informational purposes only, shelter-in-place, or evacuations, are handled through the 911 operator or the LCEMA.  These public agencies have the following notification methods at their disposal:

?    Outdoor warning sirens ? Approximately 34 sirens are located in Cheyenne.
?    Emergency Alert System ? A system through which local radio and television outlets distribute emergency information.
?    ?Code Red? ? A `reverse-911? type automatic telephone notification system that can send pre-recorded messages about an emergency at the rate of 60,000 calls per hour.  Frontier funds 50% of the annual fee associated with the

program.

Finally, Frontier?s own refinery sirens are audible to the nearby community and would likely be the first alert heard in the event of a chemical emergency.

Frontier also participates in the county?s Shelter In Place program.  This program is a countywide effort to provide information and procedures for citizens on how to survive a chemical emergency in their homes or other buildings when evacuation could be more dangerous.  The aforementioned systems and programs are communicated directly to the local residents and other potentially impacted populace by a variety of people and organizations, including city and county officials, senior refinery management, and through the county?s website (www.laramiecounty.com)

Frontier?s Planned Changes to Improve Safety at the Facility
In response to a facility siting study conducted in May, 2005, Frontier has begun design and construction on a new office building away from the process units.  Two operator shelters/control rooms and a fire house are also being designed to move operations personnel away from the immediate proximity of the process units.  The shelters will be positive pressure and will be designed to resist forces generated in the event of an explosion.
